description.p: A round-bellied halfling stirs the great iron pot, almost as large as he is, simmering over the embers of last night’s campfire. He lifts a portion of tender venison from the stew to taste before adding a pinch of salt and pepper from his pouch. The empty ladle finds the flank of the iron pot, rousing the rest of the adventuring party to breakfast with a clanging alarm. The predawn grumbling soon gives way to the licking of lips. They shall feast like kings on the hunt before diving into the necropolis hidden ahead.

A human woman, cutting an intimidating figure in her armor of patchwork skins and scales, squats on the edge of a jagged outcrop. The chimera broken across the rocks offers a unique blend of meats she can use. She begins to skin and butcher the monster, already salivating at the thought of what thrills the meal will bring. The fiery glands in the throat she saves for last, handling them carefully. Surely there is some way to incorporate the mixture into a spicy goat curry...

A drow sits in their make-up, resisting the urge to scratch at the pale stuff by sipping casually at their wine. The fools arranged around what they believe to be the table of a high elf diplomat are already many cups deep into their own. The kitchen doors swing open and the drow summons forth the servants bearing the main course - personally prepared before the arrival of the guests. They tuck in eagerly, tearing the food from the silver platters with uncivilized haste. One by one their eyes glaze over and they turn limply to the head of the table, awaiting instruction. The drow allows themselves a smile that cracks their alabaster mask open around the lips.

Each of these figures is a gourmet. A cook, and more, who has sought out the strangest, finest ingredients in the world and transformed them through their own skill into wonders for the senses. Some cook to delight others, some for gain or glory, others yet pursue new tastes purely for the love of the craft. Each of them is a unique talent whose culinary experimentation has turned then into experts on certain parts of the natural world.

The best things in life are for the bold of heart: such is as true of cooking as it is of anything else. A gourmet has the soul of a chef, but they also hold the heart of an adventurer. Their passions are combined in an endless hunt for incredible and exotic ingredients to experiment with.

What sets a gourmet apart from your common-or-garden cook is their view on - or rather, disregard for - civilised boundaries. A gourmet cares not for the stifling directions of the recipe book, but seeks inspiration in bizarre and even occasionally brilliant flavours. Their exploits cannot be contained in the kitchen: the most daring meals require daring souls who will visit far-off lands and tussle with terrible beasts, just for the chance to taste them as a well-seasoned steak.

Gourmets maintain the same skills as travelling merchants and nomadic warriors. They are hardy folk that will happily forage grubs for weeks to survive, if it means seizing the opportunity for finding a new great taste.

The fresher, the better: this is true of all cooking. And the adventuring gourmet is interested in a wide selection of wonderful meats, powders, seasoning and vegetation that can often only be found off the beaten path, to be best enjoyed that same night roasted over a crackling campfire.

Eat what you kill - this is the mantra of a gourmet. With skilled hands they can skin and fillet any number of beasts and even monsters for food. A gourmet will try anything at least once. On the road they will gather an eclectic stock of ingredients that can be added to any meal in endless combination. The travelling chef must be a master of the medley, using what they have to its best.
Using their incredible gifts as chefs, gourmets can draw out the nourishing powers of food in ways no other can come close to, working wonders in even the most trying of conditions.
description.h4: THE MOST IMPORTANT MEAL OF THE DAY
description.p: Out on the road or busy hustling in an exotic city, oftentimes a body is lucky to get one square meal a day. A gourmet can ensure that this meal is made to count, turning the humblest rations into a feast that will start any day off right. Many a group of adventurers has won the day thanks only to the skills of their daring cook. Each gourmet hones their own menu of special recipes with distinct flavours and benefits. The lasting effects of a filling meal will depend on the particular training and instincts of the cook.

When creating a gourmet, think about their connection to food and cooking. Do they love to serve others and see them satisfied, or do they seek out the most wonderful flavors for themselves? Were they formally trained, or did they learn through experimentation? Also consider what sets them apart from other cooks: their call to adventure. What drew them to take their craft on the road less traveled?

You can make a gourmet quickly by following these suggestions. First, make Constitution your highest ability score. Your next highest score should be Wisdom. Choose Intelligence instead if you plan to pick the Aberrant Cuisine specialty. Finally, choose either the Folk Hero or Guild Artisan background.
As an gourmet, you gain the following class features.

ul.li: Hit Dice: 1d12 per gourmet level
Hit Points at 1st Level: 12 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d12 (or 7) + your Constitution modifier per gourmet level after 1st
Armor: Light armor, shields.
Weapons: Simple weapons, tridents, nets.
Tools: Cook’s utensils.
Saving Throws: Constitution, Intelligence
Skills: Choose three from Animal Handling, Insight, Medicine, Nature, Persuasion, Sleight of Hand, or Survival.

description.p: You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

ul.li: (a) a set of five knives (daggers), or (b) a simple melee weapon of your choice.
(a) a sling and 20 bullets, or (b) any simple weapon.
(a) an explorer’s pack, or (b) a diplomat’s pack.
A set of padded armor and a shield.
A set of cook’s utensils, an iron pot, and 10 days of rations.

div.p: "Rather than be rich in gold or rich in friends, I only wish for riches enough to employ a good cook, so that I might - imagine! - get to dine on the richest delicacies until the end of my days."
- Dalim Zhunn, the Lean Rogue of Ratsnest.

description.p: Gourmets are often unsung heroes; their gift of cooking taken for granted as an everyday necessity, as plain as bread or cheese. But they are not mere providers. Good food raises morale like nothing else, great food can dispel exhaustion as surely as a long night’s sleep in a downy bed - and truly inspired food excites the imagination and the senses. More than anything, the enjoyment of excellent cooking bonds those around the table.

The typical image of a gourmet is the genial, jovial glue among eccentric, colorful heroes, supporting them in deeds great and small. But each gourmet has their own legacy to carve. Some live life largely as boisterous hosts, while others might stew quietly in personal turmoils, or be concocting grand ambitions for which their craft is a means to an end.
Whoever they are, whatever the reasons they cook and adventure, the sections below offer a smorgasbord of ideas to help bring out the flavour of your gourmet character.

setters.set: An expert at preparing bountiful meals to help their comrades.

description.p: A good cook wastes not and wants not. Your ingredients come not only from the pantry, but also from the creatures you encounter on your adventures. As a gourmet, you can build up a stock of special dice called Ingredient Dice by harvesting slain creatures. These dice fuel your other abilities, detailed later in this class.

At the end of each long rest, you gain a number of ingredient dice equal to 2 x your proficiency bonus, which are d6s. At 6th level, these ingredient dice turn into d8s. At 14th level, they turn into d10s.

As an action while holding your cook’s utensils or a weapon that deals slashing damage, you can begin the process of harvesting additional ingredient dice from the remains of creatures within 5 feet of you, so long as they died within the last 24 hours and are one of the following types of creature: aberrations, beasts, dragons, elementals, fiends, fey, giants, humanoids, monstrosities, oozes, or plants. The process takes 2 minutes per creature.

For each creature you successfully harvest, you gain an ingredient die equal to the size of its hit dice. For example, if you harvest a Tiny creature, you gain one ingredient die, which is a d4. If the creature was Small, the die is a d6, and so on. Ingredients harvested in this way serve as the key components of your dishes. It is assumed that you combine them with other sundries that you gather on your journey.

The maximum number of ingredient dice you can store is shown in the Stock column of the Gourmet table. If you exceed your Stock maximum when you gain a new ingredient die, you must choose ingredient dice to discard until you no longer exceed it.

div.p: Unlike class features such as Bardic Inspiration or a Monk’s ki points, your Stock is not guaranteed to be replenished to its maximum upon completing a short or long rest. Therefore, it is important for both players and DMs looking to use the Gourmet to consider the ease of access to this resource. If a campaign is likely to restrict the availability of creatures to harvest, consider allowing alternate methods to gather ingredients. For the right price, fresh ingredients could be bought in town. Exotic foodstuffs might also be looted from humanoids.

sheet.description: At the end of a long rest, you gain {{ingredient-dice:long-rest}} ingredient dice (d{{ingredient-dice:type}}s). You can store up to {{ingredient-dice:stock}} ingredient dice. For each creature you successfully harvest, you gain an ingredient die equal to the size of its hit dice. As an action, you can begin the process of harvesting ingredient dice.

description.p: Your culinary skills are crucial to extending the stamina of your adventuring party. Luckily, you have learnt to cook almost anywhere.

As long as you have access to your cook’s utensils at the end of a long rest, you can expend any number of ingredient dice in your Stock to create a meal. A meal comprises a pool of temporary hit points equal to your Wisdom modifier + the total number rolled on the expended ingredient dice. You serve a number of temporary hit points to each creature, up to the maximum amount remaining in your meal’s pool, which last until the start of a creature’s next long rest.

As you gain levels in this class, the quality of your cooking will improve and the value of your meal will multiply, as shown in the Meal Multiplier column of the Gourmet table. Apply this multiplier when determining the total pool of temporary hit points available for one of your meals.

For example, as an 5th-level gourmet with a Wisdom score of 17, you might roll 7 ingredient dice of varying sizes for a total of 27 points. Add your Wisdom modifier of 3, before applying your Meal Multiplier for a pool totaling 60 temporary hit points. You decide to serve the meal evenly amongst 3 creatures, granting each 20 temporary hit points.

sheet.description: As long as you have access to your cook’s utensils at the end of a long rest, you can create a pool of temporary hit points equal to {{wisdom:modifier}} + the total number rolled on the expended ingredient dice. You serve a number of temporary hit points to up to 6 creatures, from your meal’s pool, which last until the start of a creature’s next long rest.

As long as you have access to your cook’s utensils at the end of a long rest, you can create a pool of temporary hit points equal to 2 times ({{wisdom:modifier}} + the total number rolled on the expended ingredient dice). You serve a number of temporary hit points to up to 6 creatures, from your meal’s pool, which last until the start of a creature’s next long rest.

As long as you have access to your cook’s utensils at the end of a long rest, you can create a pool of temporary hit points equal to 3 times ({{wisdom:modifier}} + the total number rolled on the expended ingredient dice). You serve a number of temporary hit points to up to 6 creatures, from your meal’s pool, which last until the start of a creature’s next long rest.

description.p: Starting at 1st level, when a creature you can see attacks a target other than you that is within 5 feet of you, you can use your reaction to interpose yourself between the attack and its intended target, making yourself the target of the attack roll instead. You must make this decision before the attack is determined to hit or miss.

description.p: Every gourmet personalizes their craft. They may have been formally trained in a particular style of regional cuisine, or they might simply let their own tastes guide their work. As adventurers, gourmets find that their skillsets translate into an affinity with preparing different kinds of creatures. Gourmets are naturally inventive and experimental, with no two exactly alike in style. Nonetheless, they will generally fall into one of the categories described below.
When you reach 2nd level, you choose a culinary specialty, an area of expertise determined by one of several creature types which you have a personal preference for cooking with.

Select from Beast Cuisine, Monstrous Cuisine, Aberrant Cuisine, Capricious Cuisine, Rare Cuisine, Vegetarian Cuisine, Cannibal Cuisine, or Elemental Cuisine, each detailed at the end of this class description.
Your choice grants you features at 2nd level and again at 6th, 10th, and 14th level.

Cleavers, knives, or tenderizers: a good cook uses their tools with precision. At 2nd level, you adapt your ability with kitchen utensils to deploy exacting strikes on the battlefield. Choose either bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage. You gain a +2 bonus to attack rolls you make with weapons that deal your chosen damage type.
You gain a +2 bonus to attack rolls you make with weapons that deal bludgeoning damage.

description.p: At 3rd level, choose two of your skill proficiencies, or one of your skill proficiencies and your proficiency with cook’s utensils. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of the chosen proficiencies.
At 10th level, you can choose another two skill proficiencies to gain this benefit.

Starting at 3rd level, you can take charge of a busy situation with decisive momentum. Instead of moving as normal on your turn, you can convert your movement into a bold rush. The path of your rush is a straight line 5 feet wide and equal in length to your movement speed. Every creature in the line must succeed on a Strength saving throw against your Lunch Rush DC ( = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Constitution modifier) or be knocked prone. This movement does not provoke attacks of opportunity.

Starting at 5th level, you can choose to expend one ingredient die when making your Lunch Rush. Any creature that fails its save and is knocked prone takes bludgeoning damage equal to the number rolled.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Constitution modifier (a minimum of once). You regain all expended uses at the end of a long rest.

description.p: When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Beginning at 5th level, you can quickly prepare small meals and snacks to refuel your companions throughout the day. During a short rest, you can expend an ingredient die to grant a friendly creature within 30 feet of you temporary hit points equal to your Wisdom modifier + the number rolled on the expended ingredient die. The temporary hit points created by this meal do not replace those granted by your Campfire Cook feature, but instead are added to them. You can bolster up to six creatures this way per short rest, expending one ingredient die per creature.

sheet.description: During a short rest, you can grant up to 6 friendly creatures (1 die each) within 30 feet of you temporary hit points equal to {{wisdom:modifier}} + the number rolled. The temporary hit points stack with the Campfire Cook feature.

description.p: By 5th level, your adventurous diet has made you remarkably robust. You become immune to poison and disease from ingested sources.
In addition, at the start of each of your turns you can choose one of the following benefits. The benefit you choose lasts until the start of your next turn:

ul.li: Robust Blows. By throwing your weight behind your blows, you can add your Constitution modifier to the damage rolls of your melee attacks.
Sturdy Defense. By tensing yourself to withstand punishment, you can reduce the damage you take from weapon attacks by an amount equal to your Constitution modifier.

sheet.description: You are immune to poison and disease from ingested sources. At the start of each of your turns you can choose one of the following benefits that lasts until the start of your next turn: Robust Blows (+{{constitution:modifier}} damage on melee attacks). Sturdy Defense (damage reduction to weapon attacks of {{constitution:modifier}}).

description.p: From 7th level, you are able to exploit the natural bonhomie shared between those who break bread. While eating a meal at the same table, or within similar proximity to, another creature with an Intelligence score of 8 or higher, you gain advantage on Insight and Persuasion checks against that creature.

sheet.description: While sharing a meal with another creature with an Intelligence score of 8 or higher, you gain advantage on Insight and Persuasion checks against that creature.

description.p: You will ignore minor pains common to the kitchen and the battlefield when time is of the essence. Starting from 7th level, you gain resistance to acid, cold, and fire damage if you have moved since the beginning of your last turn.

In addition, choose one type of creature detailed in the Stock Up class feature. You gain two ingredient dice, instead of one, when harvesting from this creature type. You can also identify creatures as belonging to this type by sight.

description.p: At 18th level, your vast experience grants you proficiency in Wisdom and Dexterity saving throws.

At 20th level, you can reinvigorate your well-fed companions with a rousing display of bravery. As an action once per long rest, you can immediately grant additional temporary hit points equal to 10 x your Wisdom modifier to any friendly creatures that can see you within 120 feet, so long as they retain at least 1 temporary hit point granted by your Campfire Cook or Fodder Break features.

description.p: Chefs who choose this specialty favor rustic, countryside cooking: luscious roasts, thick-cut bacon butties, soups, stews, and barbeques. They are often expert hunters as well as cooks, and excel in identifying and tracking the finest game to serve as a centerpiece. Guests to such a gourmet’s table leave feeling fit to burst and as strong as an ox.
Your taste preferences have resulted in particular skill when it comes to hunting and harvesting beasts.
Beginning when you choose this specialty at 2nd level, you gain two ingredient dice, instead of one, when harvesting from creatures with the beast tag.
In addition, you can instantly identify a creature as a beast by sight.

When you choose this specialty at 2nd level, you learn how to tease out the true succulence of your protein-packed ingredients. When you create a meal using your Campfire Cook feature, you can choose one effect of the enhance ability spell. A number of creatures of your choice equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum 1) that partake of the meal gain this effect. The effect does not require concentration to maintain, and persists so long as a creature retains temporary hit points from your meal. If the Bear’s Endurance effect is chosen, the 2d6 additional temporary hit points are rolled separately for each creature effected, and are added to the total of temporary hit points they receive from your meal.

sheet.description: When you create a meal, you can choose one effect of the enhance ability spell. Up to {{wild-roast:targets}} creatures of your choice that partake of the meal gain this effect. If the Bear’s Endurance effect is chosen, the 2d6 additional temporary hit points are rolled separately for each creature effected, and are added to the total of temporary hit points they receive from your meal.

description.p: Also at 2nd level, your meals gain a full-bodied focus that helps banish fatigue. A creature eating one of your meals can expend 5 temporary hit points granted by the meal to cure one level of exhaustion affecting itself. Multiple levels of exhaustion can be cured during a single serving, with temporary hit points expended separately for each level.

sheet.description: A creature eating one of your meals can expend 5 temporary hit points granted by the meal to cure one level of exhaustion affecting itself.

description.p: Starting at 6th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

sheet.description: You can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

description.p: By 10th level, you have perfected the deft capture of your quarry, combining your hunting and cooking techniques of meat tying. You can use your Animal Handling instead of Athletics when attempting to grapple a creature, or to contest a grapple. While grappling a creature, you can use a bonus action to quickly bind its limbs and body. The creature is considered restrained. The effect persists even if you release your hold on it. The creature can use an action to attempt to break free, as if from a normal grapple, by contesting your original grapple roll. On a success, it is no longer restrained.

sheet.description: You can use your Animal Handling instead of Athletics when attempting to grapple a creature, or to contest a grapple. While grappling a creature, you can use a bonus action to quickly bind its limbs and body. The creature is considered restrained.

description.p: Also starting at 10th level, you treat creatures as one size larger for the purposes of harvesting ingredient dice. For example, Tiny creatures now offer a d6, Small creatures a d8, and so on. The size of an ingredient die cannot exceed d20.

sheet.description: You treat creatures as one size larger for the purposes of harvesting ingredient dice.

description.p: At 14th level, your skill as a hunter is equal to your talent as a cook. When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can opt to target its vital points and prematurely expend its ingredient die, adding the damage rolled + your Wisdom modifier to your total damage for the attack. A creature targeted in this way cannot be harvested using your Stock Up feature once killed.
When targeting creatures that have the beast tag with this feature, you can prematurely expend two ingredient dice, instead of one.

sheet.description: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can opt to target its vital points and prematurely expend its ingredient die (two for beasts), adding the damage rolled + {{wisdom:modifier}} to your total damage for the attack. A creature targeted in this way cannot be harvested using your Stock Up feature once killed.

description.p: In a world filled with strange and dangerous monsters, it only took so long for reckless souls to ask: can you survive eating the sting of a manticore? And if so, what would it taste like? Gourmets who are known as specialists in monster cuisine are hardy (and often heavily-scarred) cooks who are as ready to wrestle gorgons as they are to knead dough. They are the first to try untested, possibly poisonous, ingredients, and dive into the lairs of local horrors without hesitation to follow the rumour of a new ingredient. To them, a dare is as good as an order from a paying customer, with the price of life and limb no object in the pursuit of bold cooking.
Your taste preferences have resulted in particular skill when it comes to hunting and harvesting monstrosities.
Beginning when you choose this specialty at 2nd level, you gain two ingredient dice instead of one when harvesting from creatures with the monstrosity tag.
In addition, you can instantly identify a creature as a monstrosity by sight.
When you choose this specialty at 2nd level, you gain proficiency with medium armor and martial weapons.

Also at 2nd level, you learn to boil the glands and giblets of your foes down into a bracing bile reminiscent of troll oils. At the end of a long rest, you create a small, yellowish elixir in an empty flask or waterskin. As a bonus action, you can consume the elixir to gain a temporary regenerative effect that lasts for 1 minute. While the effect of the elixir is active, you regain hit points equal to half of your gourmet level (rounded down) at the start of each of your turns.

If you take acid or fire damage, the regenerative effect doesn’t function at the start of your next turn. If you start your turn with 0 hit points and are able to regenerate, the effect of the elixir ends immediately afterward.
If a creature other than yourself consumes one of your elixirs, they do not gain its effects, and must succeed on a DC 20 Constitution saving throw or become poisoned for 1 hour.

sheet.description: At the end of a long rest, you create an elixir in an empty flask or waterskin. As a bonus action, you can consume the elixir to gain a temporary regenerative effect that lasts for 1 minute. While the effect of the elixir is active, you regain {{level:gourmet:half}} hit points at the start of each of your turns.

description.p: From 6th level, you can turn the natural abilities of your prey against them through your culinary experience. When you create a meal using your Campfire Cook feature, you can choose two conditions from the following list: blinded, charmed, deafened, paralyzed, petrified, or poisoned. A creature that partakes of the meal gains advantage on saving throws against the chosen conditions for 12 hours, or until it is knocked unconscious.
At 10th level, you become permanently immune to two conditions of your choice, selected from those listed.

When you hit a creature with an attack using the poisoned weapon, you deal one die of poison damage to the target, in addition to the weapon’s damage. The die is equal in size to the largest ingredient die you expended during the rest.

When a creature takes this additional damage, you can expend an ingredient die to force it to make a Constitution saving throw (DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier). On a failure, the creature is poisoned for 1 minute.

sheet.description: When you intercept an attack using your Guts feature and the attack hits you, you can treat the damage of the attack as though your Sturdy Defense is active. In addition, once per long rest when you fail a Constitution saving throw, you can reroll your save. You must accept the new result.

description.p: At 14th level, your skill and savagery allows you to instantly tear an ingredient die free from a harvestable creature when you slay it. As a bonus action when you perform this special harvest, you can emit a guttural roar that evokes the very monsters you slay. All hostile creatures that can hear you within 60 feet must make a Wisdom saving throw against your Raw & Bloody DC ( = 8 + your proficiency bonus + the maximum roll for your specially harvested ingredient die). Creatures that fail the saving throw are frightened of you for 1 hour. At the end of each of its turns, a creature can make a further Charisma saving throw. On a success, the effect ends. A creature that succeeds on its saving throw is immune to this effect for 24 hours.
Once you use this feature, you must complete a short or long rest before you are able to use it again.

sheet.description: You to instantly tear an ingredient die free from a harvestable creature when you slay it. As a bonus action when you perform this special harvest, you can emit a guttural roar that evokes the very monsters you slay. All hostile creatures that can hear you within 60 feet must make a Wisdom saving throw (DC {{raw-and-bloody:save-base}} + the maximum roll for your specially harvested ingredient die). Creatures that fail the saving throw are frightened of you for 1 hour.

description.p: All gourmets have adventurous appetites. Those who chase the taste of aberrant cuisine push the palate farther than even most of their peers can stomach. They are fascinated by the possibilities of strange or otherworldly foods that rarely find their way onto the Prime Material Plane. These cooks are often obsessive about recording the details of their dives into the unknown, though such recipes are unlikely to be written in a legible hand, or to be recognized as edible at all. Many gourmets of this persuasion exude an unsettling, invasive air. A steady diet of foodstuffs outside of mortal comprehension can wreak bizarre changes to the tastebuds ... and the mind.
Your taste preferences have resulted in particular skill when it comes to hunting and harvesting aberrations.
Beginning when you choose this specialty at 2nd level, you gain two ingredient dice, instead of one, when harvesting from creatures with the aberration tag.
In addition, you can instantly identify a creature as an aberration by sight.

By choosing this specialty at 2nd level, you follow your tastes down a peculiar path that leaves common wisdom far behind. Whenever a gourmet feature uses your Wisdom modifier, you can use your Intelligence modifier instead.

sheet.description: Whenever a gourmet feature uses your Wisdom modifier, you can use your Intelligence modifier instead.

description.p: When you choose this specialty at 2nd level, you become convinced that including a few unearthly maggots in your dishes can only ever be a good thing. When friendly creatures partake of a meal created using your Campfire Cook feature, they gain a shared mental connection with one another that lasts 12 hours, or until their next long rest. They can communicate telepathically with other creatures that consumed the meal up to a range equal to your Intelligence modifier x 100 feet (minimum 0).

As an action while your network is active, you can expend an ingredient die to detect creatures that can be harvested using your Stock Up feature. You learn the location, as well as the type, of any such creature within 60 feet of you. The probe can penetrate barriers, but 2 feet of rock, 2 inches of any metal other than lead, or a thin sheet of lead blocks you.

sheet.description: When friendly creatures partake of a meal created using your Campfire Cook feature, they gain a shared mental connection with one another that lasts 12 hours, or until their next long rest. They can communicate telepathically with other creatures that consumed the meal up to a {{parasitic-delicacy:range}}-foot range. As an action while your network is active, you can expend an ingredient die to detect creatures that can be harvested using your Stock Up feature. You learn the location, as well as the type, of any such creature within 60 feet of you.

description.p: Beginning at 6th level, your palate has developed enough to take in psychic flavours as well as physical ones. When you are harvesting ingredient dice from a creature, you can choose to forgo gaining any dice and instead immediately consume part of that creature, gaining some of its recent memories.

You can choose one of the creature’s skill proficiencies, if it had any, and substitute its bonuses for your own for 1 hour. For up to 10 minutes after consumption, you can explore the memories of events that the target experienced within the last 24 hours. You can hone in on particular events that lasted no more than 10 minutes in detail. Otherwise, you gain a general summary of the creature’s experiences. You can recall what you learned afterwards as accurately as if accessing your own memories.

sheet.description: When you are harvesting ingredient dice from a creature, you can choose to forgo gaining any dice and instead immediately consume part of that creature, gaining some of its recent memories. You can choose one of the creature’s skill proficiencies, if it had any, and substitute its bonuses for your own for 1 hour. For up to 10 minutes after consumption, you can explore the memories of events that the target experienced within the last 24 hours.

description.p: Starting at 6th level, you can trigger the panic of starvation in your foes by invading their sensory centers with psychic tastes and smells. When a hostile creature moves within 10 feet of you for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, that creature must make a Intelligence saving throw against your False Hunger DC ( = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier). On a failed save, the creature takes psychic damage equal to your Intelligence modifier.
A creature that does not need to eat or drink is immune to this effect.

sheet.description: When a hostile creature moves within 10 feet of you for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, that creature must make a Intelligence saving throw (DC {{false-hunger:save-dc}}). On a failed save, the creature takes {{intelligence:modifier}} psychic damage. A creature that does not need to eat or drink is immune to this effect.

description.p: Starting at 10th level, when a creature that forms part of your Parasitic Delicacy network is forced to make an Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma saving throw, they can choose to use the save bonus of any other creature currently in the network in place of their own. Multiple creatures can choose the same bonus to use at the same time.

Saves can be substituted in this way a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum 0). If multiple creatures substitute a save at the same time, each creature expends a use of this feature. You regain all expended uses after completing a long rest.

sheet.description: When a creature that forms part of your Parasitic Delicacy network is forced to make an Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma saving throw, they can choose to use the save bonus of any other creature currently in the network in place of their own. Multiple creatures can choose the same bonus to use at the same time. If multiple creatures substitute a save at the same time, each creature expends a use of this feature.

description.p: By 14th level, your unusual diet has wrought permanent changes upon your mind. You become immune to hostile telepathy. If a creature attempts to breach your mind or contact you telepathically without prior consent, you become aware of this, as well as the general direction and distance to the source of the signal, but are otherwise unaffected.
In addition, your Intelligence score increase by 2. Your Intelligence score maximum is now 22.

sheet.description: You are immune to hostile telepathy. If a creature attempts to breach your mind or contact you telepathically without prior consent, you become aware of this, as well as the general direction and distance to the source of the signal, but are otherwise unaffected.

description.p: The power to please, and therefore to manipulate, is a tempting reward for the years of work required to learn any fine craft. Some gourmets are attracted to the vocation for just such opportunities. They use their culinary skills to practice a kind of black magic, constructing alluring feasts and blending potions of ill intent. Practitioners know that the flesh of the conniving fey is the secret ingredient of many double-edged delights. They also emulate the tricky nature of such creatures: drawing in, pampering, and deceiving their patrons with the subtle spice of sylvan magic... always ready to turn on them the moment an irresistible advantage presents itself.
Your taste preferences have resulted in particular skill when it comes to hunting and harvesting fey.
Beginning when you choose this specialty at 2nd level, you gain two ingredient dice, instead of one, when harvesting from creatures with the fey tag.
In addition, you can instantly identify a creature as a fey by sight.
When you choose this specialty at 2nd level, you gain proficiency with the poisoner’s kit and in the Deception skill.

In addition, when you use the Help action to assist an ally with an ability check or attack roll, you can choose another creature within 5 feet of that ally. The chosen creature gains disadvantage on the first ability check or attack roll it makes against a target other than you before the start of your next turn.

sheet.description: When you use the Help action to assist an ally with an ability check or attack roll, you can choose another creature within 5 feet of that ally. The chosen creature gains disadvantage on the first ability check or attack roll it makes against a target other than you before the start of your next turn.

description.p: When you choose this specialty at 2nd level, you learn to turn your talents for hosting into a chance for trickery. By spending thirty minutes with your cook’s utensils, you can create a meal using the same method as your Campfire Cook feature, and secretly fill it with bewitching poisons. The meal’s value equals half of its usual total (rounded down).

Up to six creatures of your choice that partake of the meal must make a Constitution saving throw against your Witches’ Brew DC ( = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier). On a success, a creature notices a bad taste in the food but is otherwise unaffected. On a failure, a creature is charmed by you for a number of hours equal to your Wisdom modifier, or until you or your companions do anything harmful to it. The charmed creature regards you as a good friend. In addition, the meal’s value is subtracted from a creature’s maximum hit points for the duration. When the effect ends, the creature knows it was charmed by you.
The meals true contents can be revealed by a detect poison and disease spell, but cannot be guarded against by effects such as protection from poison or purify food and drink.

sheet.description: By spending thirty minutes with your cook’s utensils, you can create a meal using the same method as your Campfire Cook feature, and secretly fill it with bewitching poisons. The meal’s value equals half of its usual total (rounded down). Up to six creatures of your choice that partake of the meal must make a Constitution saving throw (DC {{witches-brew:save-dc}}) or be charmed for {{wisdom:modifier}} hours.

description.p: By 6th level, the dangerous allure of your dishes is enough to draw the nose of creatures with the force of a physical gesture. As an action, you can expend one ingredient die to cook up swirls of tantalizing steam that radiate from you in an aura with a 30-foot radius. The steam lasts for 1 minute.

A hostile creature with a working sense of smell that starts its turn in the aura must make a Wisdom saving throw against your Witches’ Brew DC. On a failed save, the creature is compelled to spend at least half of its movement speed to move towards you.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (a minimum of once). You regain all expended uses at the end of a long rest.

sheet.description: You can expend one ingredient die to cook up swirls of tantalizing steam that radiate from you in an aura with a 30-foot radius. The steam lasts for 1 minute. A hostile creature with a working sense of smell that starts its turn in the aura must make a Wisdom saving throw (DC {{witches-brew:save-dc}}) or be compelled to spend at least half of its movement speed to move towards you.

description.p: From 10th level, you can touch a creature as an action to extend your hospitality to it. An unwilling creature must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against your Witches’ Brew DC to resist the effect. The targeted creature immediately turns invisible, and cannot be heard, smelt, or otherwise perceived by creatures other than you that do not possess truesight. Any conditions currently affecting the target are transferred to you, and any temporary hit points you have are transferred to the creature. If you are under the effects of a beneficial spell of 5th-level or lower, such as haste, you can also choose to transfer the spell to the target creature. Your hospitality lasts for 1 hour, or until you choose to withdraw it as a bonus action.

When your hospitality is withdrawn, the target creature immediately loses any benefits you have granted it. Any temporary hit points the target creature has return to you, and any conditions currently affecting you are transferred to the target creature. In addition, the target creature becomes vulnerable to all damage until the start of its next turn. The next attack roll made against the creature before the start of its next turn has advantage.
Once you use this feature, you must complete a short or long rest before you can use it again.

sheet.description: You touch a creature. An unwilling creature must make a Wisdom saving throw (DC {{witches-brew:save-dc}}) or immediately turn invisible, and cannot be detected except by truesight. Conditions affecting the target transfer to you and your temporary hit points transfer to them. You can choose to transfer the effects of a spell of 5th level or lower to the target.

description.p: At 14th level, you can expend one ingredient die as part of a Charisma (Deception) or Charisma (Persuasion) check to grant yourself advantage on the check by offering a small treat of the target’s liking. If the target consumes the offering, you can choose to have it immediately fall under the effects of your Witches’ Brew feature. The value for the offering to subtract from the target’s maximum hit points equals your Wisdom score + your gourmet level.

sheet.description: You can expend one ingredient die as part of a Deception or Persuasion check to grant yourself advantage on the check by offering a small treat of the target’s liking. If the target consumes the offering, you can choose to have it immediately fall under the effects of your Witches’ Brew feature. The offering subtracts {{seductive-sweetmeats:hp}} from the target’s maximum hit points.

description.p: Trained in exclusive dining clubs or renowned restaurants, practitioners of this cuisine exude confidence in their cooking ability and use it as a form of expressing their affluence. And nothing is as tellingly rich as dragon meat. Meals crafted with such rarefied ingredients are known to light a fire in the belly and leave a delightful aftertaste that can linger on the tongue for hours. Some consider these individuals snobbish, but like all gourmets, they carry a deep love of excellent cooking. Dragon scales and fangs are hunted by many for their rumoured mystical and medicinal properties -- but the gourmet knows that the true value of such a trophy must be brought out in the skillet.
Your taste preferences have resulted in particular skill when it comes to hunting and harvesting dragons.
Beginning when you choose this specialty at 2nd level, you gain two ingredient dice instead of one when harvesting from creatures with the dragon tag.
In addition, you can instantly identify a creature as a dragon by sight.

Starting at 2nd level, while you retain the temporary hit points granted by your Campfire Cook feature, your body takes on a slightly lustrous sheen, and you add half of your Wisdom modifier, rounded down, to your Charisma skill checks.

sheet.description: While you retain the temporary hit points granted by your Campfire Cook feature, you add half of your Wisdom modifier, rounded down, to your Charisma skill checks.

description.p: You have also developed the dragons’ famous nose for gold. Also at 2nd level, you can use your action to inhale and open your olfactory channels to detect treasures. Until the end of your next turn, you detect the presence and direction of any precious gemstones, gold, platinum, or silver objects within 100 feet of you. You know the type of material and gain a general sense of its quantity. Your sense of smell can penetrate most barriers, but is blocked by 1 foot of solid stone, 1 inch of common metal, a thin sheet of lead, or 3 feet of wood or dirt.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to 1 + your Constitution modifier. When you finish a long rest, you regain all expended uses.

sheet.description: Until the end of your next turn, you detect the presence and direction of any precious gemstones, gold, platinum, or silver objects within 100 feet of you.

description.p: Starting at 6th level, you can concoct recipes that mimic the rare taste of dragon cuisine. When a friendly creature partakes of a meal created using your Campfire Cook feature, it gains a stored version of the 2nd-level spell dragon’s breath that remains stored for 8 hours, or until the creature is knocked unconscious.

As a bonus action, a creature can release this spell to instantly cast it upon themselves. The stored spell is then consumed. When the spell is cast in this way, it does not require material components or concentration.

sheet.description: When a friendly creature partakes of a meal created using your Campfire Cook feature, it gains a stored version of the 2nd-level spell dragon’s breath that remains stored for 8 hours, or until the creature is knocked unconscious. As a bonus action, a creature can release this spell to instantly cast it upon themselves.

description.p: By 10th level, your draconic diet has nurtured magic in your blood that you can use to rebalance a situation moving out of your control. When a creature that retains temporary hit points from one of your gourmet features is within 60 feet of you and rolls a 1 on an attack roll or saving throw, you can use your reaction to expend an ingredient die and imbue it with a sudden wealth of energy. Translucent, colored scales bloom on its body, granting it a +2 bonus to AC until the end of its next turn. The next attack roll or saving throw it makes before the end of its next turn is automatically a 20.
Additionally, you gain a +1 to your AC whenever you have temporary hit points from one of your gourmet features.

sheet.description: When a creature that retains temporary hit points from one of your gourmet features is within 60 feet of you and rolls a 1 on an attack roll or saving throw, you can expend an ingredient die and imbue it with a sudden wealth of energy. You grant it a +2 bonus to AC until the end of its next turn. The next attack roll or saving throw it makes before the end of its next turn is automatically a 20. Additionally, you gain a +1 to your AC whenever you have temporary hit points from one of your gourmet features.

description.p: By 14th level, your appetites are practically indistinguishable from those of a true dragon. You gain proficiency in Charisma saving throws, and you can now consume gold as if it were ordinary food. For every 1000gp that you eat, your hit point maximum and your Charisma score increase by 1. You can gain a maximum of 50 additional hit points in this way. Your Charisma score maximum is now 22.

sheet.description: You can consume gold as if it were ordinary food.

description.p: Adventurers who pursue this craft seek healthy alternatives to culinary classics by innovating with the humble, often-unsung vegetable. The provisions of nature are many, and a skilled cook can make a varied, vibrant diet without meat ever gracing the plate. Gourmets who specialize in such cooking are experts at selecting and preparing a bounty of greens that will enhance the overall health benefits of their diners: baking, grilling, steaming, or frying up a colorful culinary experience that boasts an extra zing in every bite and puts an extra spring into their companions’ step.
Your taste preferences have resulted in particular skill when it comes to hunting and harvesting plants.
Beginning when you choose this specialty at 2nd level, you gain two ingredient dice instead of one when harvesting from creatures with the plant tag.
In addition, you can instantly identify a creature as a plant by sight.

Your meals invigorate guests with extra energy that can be expressed in sudden bursts of speed. Starting from when you choose this specialty at 2nd level, a creature has its movement speed increased by 10 feet so long as it retains temporary hit points from your Campfire Cook meal. This bonus increases to 15 feet at 10th level, and to 20 feet at 14th level.

A creature can choose to expend 10 temporary hit points granted by the meal to add your Wisdom modifier to a Dexterity saving throw. Whenever it does so, its movement speed increases by 10 feet until the end of its next turn.

sheet.description: A creature has its movement speed increased by {{zest-and-zeal:speed-bonus}} feet so long as it retains temporary hit points from your Campfire Cook meal. A creature can choose to expend 10 temporary hit points granted by the meal to add {{wisdom:modifier}} to a Dexterity saving throw. Whenever it does so, its movement speed increases by 10 feet until the end of its next turn.

description.p: Starting from 2nd level, your skill in botany allows you to nurture high-quality ingredients from natural sources. You gain proficiency in the Nature skill, and when you end a long rest in terrain capable of sustaining plant life, you add one extra ingredient die to your stock, which is a d8.
At 6th level, this ingredient die becomes a d10. At 14th level, it becomes a d12.

sheet.description: When you end a long rest in terrain capable of sustaining plant life, you add one extra d8 d{{cultivate:die-type}} to your stock.

description.p: From 6th level, whenever you use your Lunch Rush feature, you can take the Help action as a bonus action. Additionally, when you use the Help action in this way, the ally you assist can be anywhere within 5 feet of the line of your movement.

sheet.description: Whenever you use your Lunch Rush feature, you can take the Help action as a bonus action. Additionally, when you use the Help action in this way, the ally you assist can be anywhere within 5 feet of the line of your movement.

description.p: At 10th level, your meals actively enhance the senses. A creature that partakes of your Campfire Cook meal gains darkvision out to a distance of 30 feet until the start of its next long rest. If it already has darkvision, its range increases by 30 feet. While a creatures retains temporary hit point from your gourmet features, it adds your Wisdom modifier to initiative rolls, and it cannot be surprised.

sheet.description: A creature that partakes of your Campfire Cook meal gains darkvision out to a distance of 30 feet until the start of its next long rest. If it already has darkvision, its range increases by 30 feet. While a creatures retains temporary hit point from your gourmet features, it adds {{wisdom:modifier}} to initiative rolls, and it cannot be surprised.

description.p: Also at 10th level, you can expend 4 ingredient dice to cast plant growth as if it were a ritual.
You must complete a long rest before you can use this feature again.

sheet.description: You can expend 4 ingredient dice to cast plant growth as if it were a ritual.

description.p: Beginning at 14th level, a creature that retains temporary hit points from your Campfire Cook meal can add your Wisdom modifier to its Dexterity saving throws without expending temporary hit points.

sheet.description: A creature that retains temporary hit points from your Campfire Cook meal can add {{wisdom:modifier}} to its Dexterity saving throws without expending temporary hit points.

description.p: Some societies, including the tribes of the cold-minded Lizardmen, have normalized the appetites of cannibalism: the practice of eating others of your own kind. These cultures are few and far-between -- most civilizations agree it is one of the ultimate taboos. In the wilderness, however, the desperate can discover that they have the stomach for anything, if they might only survive. Individuals with a talent for cooking can become grim gourmets indeed under the threat of starvation.

Others pursue this craft purposefully, as the butchers and blood-ministers of cults or communities dedicated to wicked gods. Whatever the path taken - neutral, regrettable, or reprehensible - the genuine skill of a true cannibal gourmet must be acknowledged. Without formal learning (for such records are routinely burned), they can create unsettingly mouth-watering recipes that offer new life out of death.
Your taste preferences have resulted in particular skill when it comes to hunting and harvesting humanoids.
Beginning when you choose this specialty at 2nd level, you gain two ingredient dice instead of one when harvesting from creatures with the humanoid tag.
In addition, you can instantly identify a creature as a humanoid by sight.

Starting at 2nd level, you learn to shadow a target you have marked for consumption. As a bonus action, choose a creature that you can see within 120 feet of you. The target must succeed on a Wisdom (Insight) check against your Personal Chef DC (= 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier). On a failure, the target is marked by your bloodlust for 24 hours.

A marked target has disadvantage on Wisdom (Insight) and Wisdom (Perception) checks related to you. Once per turn when you hit the marked target with a weapon attack, you can immediately make a second attack against the same target as part of the same action. If necessary, you draw a new weapon or piece of ammunition as part of this attack. This attack is a critical hit on a roll of 19 or higher.
The target ceases being marked if it dies, you mark another creature, or if you choose to release it as a bonus action.
You can use this feature twice. You regain all expended uses at the end of a short or long rest.

sheet.description: Choose a creature that you can see within 120 feet of you. The target must succeed on a Insight check against (DC {{personal-chef:save-dc}}). On a failure, the target is marked by your bloodlust for 24 hours. A marked target has disadvantage on Insight and Perception checks related to you. Once per turn when you hit the marked target with a weapon attack, you can immediately make a second attack against the same target as part of the same action. This attack is a critical hit on a roll of 19 or higher.

description.p: Also starting from 2nd level, you can forgo adding an ingredient die to your stock when you are harvesting from a creature and instead instantly consume it, recovering a number of hit points equal to the number rolled on the consumed ingredient die + your Constitution modifier.
When consuming creatures that have the humanoid tag in this way, you can roll two ingredient dice, instead of one.
Once you use this feature, you must finish a short rest before you can use it again.

sheet.description: You can forgo adding an ingredient die to your stock when you are harvesting from a creature and instead instantly consume it, recovering a number of hit points equal to the number rolled on the consumed ingredient die + {{constitution:modifier}}. When consuming creatures that have the humanoid tag in this way, you can roll two ingredient dice, instead of one.

description.p: Beginning from 6th level, creatures that partake of your Campfire Cook meal gain an enhanced appetite for violence until the start of their next long rest. Once per turn, when a creature that you have fed misses an attack against a target within 30 feet and the target is missing any of its hit points, the creature can re-roll its attack against that target.

sheet.description: Creatures that partake of your Campfire Cook meal gain an enhanced appetite for violence until the start of their next long rest. Once per turn, when a creature that you have fed misses an attack against a target within 30 feet and the target is missing any of its hit points, the creature can re-roll its attack against that target.

description.p: By 10th level, your mind is dissociated from the horrors you see inflicted by your own blades. When you deal damage to a creature with an attack, you gain resistance to psychic damage and gain a +1 bonus to your Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws until the start of your next turn.

sheet.description: When you deal damage to a creature with an attack, you gain resistance to psychic damage and gain a +1 bonus to your Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws until the start of your next turn.

description.p: By 14th level, your hunger for blood is equal to that of a berserker. If the second attack granted by your Personal Chef feature is a critical hit, you can make a third attack against the same target as part of the same action. If necessary, you draw a new weapon or piece of ammunition as part of this attack. This attack is a critical hit on a roll of 18 or higher.

sheet.description: If the second attack granted by your Personal Chef feature is a critical hit, you can make a third attack against the same target as part of the same action. This attack is a critical hit on a roll of 18 or higher.

description.p: Gourmets of this persuasion have been inspired by the way that the ingredients of the universe can be broken down into their most basic parts and endlessly recombined into new recipes. Experimenters and inventors at heart, they have an affinity for the study and manipulation of the elements, the very building blocks of all flavor, matter, and power, that elevates their molecular gastronomy to a method not unlike alchemy. With an accompaniment of arcane magic, these curious cooks create burning spices, silky-smooth sauces, air-light pastries, and deep textures unlike any other. When called to action as part of an adventuring band, they can use these lessons in fusion to enhance the effects of their spellwork, as well.

When you choose this specialty at 2nd level, you enhance your cooking and combat skill with the ability to cast spells. See chapter 10 of the Player’s Handbook for the general rules of spellcasting and chapter 11 for the wizard spell list.
Cantrips. You learn three cantrips: produce flame and two other cantrips of your choice from the wizard spell list. You learn an additional wizard cantrip of your choice at 10th level.

Spell Slots. The Elemental Cuisine Spellcasting table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a spell slot of the spell’s level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.
For example, if you know the 1st-level spell burning hands and have a 1st and a 2nd-level spell slot available, you can cast burning hands using either slot.
Spells Known of 1st-Level and Higher. You know three 1st-level wizard spells of your choice, two of which you must choose from the conjuration and evocation spells on the wizard spell list.

The Spells Known column of the Elemental Cuisine Spellcasting table shows when you learn more wizard spells of 1st level or higher. Each of these spells must be a conjuration or evocation spell of your choice, and must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For instance, when you reach 7th level in this class, you can learn one new spell of 1st or 2nd level.
The spells you learn at 8th, 14th, and 20th level can come from any school of magic.

Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace one of the wizard spells you know with another spell of your choice from the wizard spell list. The new spell must be of a level for which you have spell slots, and it must be a conjuration or evocation spell, unless you’re replacing the spell you gained at 8th, 14th, or 20th level.

Spellcasting Ability. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for your wizard spells, since you apply your learning through the medium of your cooking. You use your Wisdom whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Wisdom modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a wizard spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.
Spell Save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier
Spell attack modifier = your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier
Your taste preferences have resulted in particular skill when it comes to hunting and harvesting elementals.
Beginning when you choose this specialty at 2nd level, you gain two ingredient dice, instead of one, when harvesting from creatures with the elemental tag.
In addition, you can instantly identify a creature as an elemental by sight.

When you choose this specialty at 2nd level, you train in the critical skills necessary to savor the elements as primal ingredients, just as satiating as any food. When you are targeted by or included in the area of effect of a spell, attack, or other effect that deals acid, cold, fire, lightning, thunder, or bludgeoning damage, you gain advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks related to the corresponding element for 1 hour.

In addition, whenever you are subjected to damage of any of the types listed above and you have resistance to that damage, you can expend an ingredient die to absorb the resisted element instead, taking no damage and instead regaining a number of temporary hit points equal to the damage dealt. These temporary hit point stack with those granted by your other gourmet features.

sheet.description: hen you are targeted by or included in the area of effect of a spell, attack, or other effect that deals acid, cold, fire, lightning, thunder, or bludgeoning damage, you gain advantage on Arcana checks related to the corresponding element for 1 hour. In addition, whenever you are subjected to damage of any of the types listed above and you have resistance to that damage, you can expend an ingredient die to absorb the resisted element instead, taking no damage and instead regaining a number of temporary hit points equal to the damage dealt. These temporary hit point stack with those granted by your other gourmet features.

description.p: Starting at 6th level, your recipes interact with elemental magic in ways that continue to deliver an exhilarating culinary experience long after the last bite. When a friendly creature partakes of a meal created using your Campfire Cook feature, it gains a stored version of the 1st-level spell absorb elements that remains stored for 8 hours, or until the creature is knocked unconscious.
As a reaction when it takes acid, cold, fire, lightning, or thunder damage, a creature can release this spell to instantly cast it upon themselves. The stored spell is then consumed.

sheet.description: When a friendly creature partakes of a meal created using your Campfire Cook feature, it gains a stored version of the 1st-level spell absorb elements that remains stored for 8 hours, or until the creature is knocked unconscious. As a reaction when it takes acid, cold, fire, lightning, or thunder damage, a creature can release this spell to instantly cast it upon themselves. The stored spell is then consumed.

description.p: At 10th level, you learn the spell create or destroy water. The spell doesn’t count against your number of spells known, and you can cast it without needing material components. You can also cast the spell create food and water once per long rest.

Additionally, while you have room in your Stock, you can expend one gourmet spell slot as an action to create an ingredient die. A 1st-level spell slot creates a d8. The ingredient die’s size increases by one for each slot level above 1st. For example, a 2nd-level spell slot creates a d10.

sheet.description: You can also cast the spell create food and water once per long rest. Additionally, while you have room in your Stock, you can expend one gourmet spell slot as an action to create an ingredient die. 1st > d8. 2nd > d10. 3rd > d12. 4th > d20.

description.p: Starting at 10th level, when you cast a spell of 1st level or higher, you can expend an ingredient die to prepare one of the effects listed below as part of the spell.
Once you use this feature, you must complete a short rest before you can do so again.
The fusions are presented in alphabetical order.

Deconstructed. You draw out the ingredients of water to change a spell. You can convert the damage type of the spell to one from the following list: acid, cold, fire, lightning, thunder, or bludgeoning. The first time the spell deals damage, it also deals additional damage equal to the number rolled on your expended ingredient die.
Kick it Up. You draw out the ingredients of fire to enhance a spell attack. Add the number rolled on the expended ingredient die to your spell attack roll.
Rustic Charm. You draw out the ingredients of earth to enhance the weight of a spell. Add half the number rolled on the expended ingredient die, rounded up, to your spell save DC for this spell.

With a Twist. You draw out the ingredients of air to enhance a ranged spell attack. Add the number rolled on the expended ingredient die x 5 to the spell’s range in feet. The spell can now also move around corners if necessary, and ignores three-quarters cover and half cover to reach its target if it is in range.

sheet.description: When you cast a spell of 1st level or higher, you can expend an ingredient die to prepare one experimental fusion as part of the spell.

description.p: By 14th level, your understanding of the way the elements combine and recombine has reached a near-innate level that allows you to draw their power directly from your own sustenance.

When you cast a spell with a casting time of an action that deals either acid, cold, fire, lightning, thunder, or bludgeoning damage, you can choose to convert any temporary hit points you have, up to a total number equal to 2 x your gourmet level, into additional damage as part of that same action. For every temporary hit point you convert, the spell deals an additional 1 damage of the associated element.

sheet.description: When you cast a spell with a casting time of an action that deals either acid, cold, fire, lightning, thunder, or bludgeoning damage, you can choose to convert up to {{stirring-energies:bonus}} temporary hit points you have into additional damage as part of that same action. For every temporary hit point you convert, the spell deals an additional 1 damage of the associated element.

description.p: Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any check you make with Cook’s Utensils.

description.p: Delectable jellied desserts are a classic of the kitchen; demon-spawned gelatinous killers, a classic of the dungeon. To see the two combined in the imagination of a gourmet was inevitable. Some chefs seeking their signature style will discover it on the walls of the dank, deep crawls their travels take them to, and set their mind to alchemizing their own sweet and sour oddities in the dessert mold. Gourmets gifted with the tastebuds to withstand the acidic burn of these ingredients can concoct incredible, technically-edible, wobbling wonders just oozing with flavor. Their own biology may, regrettably, lose its cohesion along the way.
Your taste preferences have resulted in particular skill when it comes to hunting and harvesting oozes.
Beginning when you choose this specialty at 2nd level, you gain two ingredient dice, instead of one, when harvesting from creatures with the ooze tag.
In addition, you can instantly identify a creature as a ooze by sight.
When you choose this specialty at 2nd level, you gain proficiency with alchemist’s supplies and poisoner’s kits.

From 2nd level, when you create a meal using your Campfire Cook feature you gain a climb speed equal to your walking speed that lasts for 8 hours. You can cling to and move upside down along ceilings while climbing. You also gain advantage on Strength or Dexterity checks and saving throws made to grab or keep hold of an object for the duration.

As an action, you can give the benefit of this feature to a creature that you touch. The shared benefit lasts for 1 hour. Once you extend this benefit to another creature, you can’t do so again until you next use your Campfire Cook feature, or unless you choose to give up your own benefits to do so.

You can cling to and move upside down along ceilings while climbing. You also gain advantage on Strength or Dexterity checks and saving throws made to grab or keep hold of an object for the duration. As an action, you can give the benefit of this feature to a creature that you touch. The shared benefit lasts for 1 hour. description.p: Starting from 6th level, you can use your cook’s utensils to create living jellies of your own. During a short or long rest, you can expend ingredient dice to create a pool of hit points using the same method as your Campfire Cook feature. From this pool, you create a number of sickly trifles in unoccupied spaces on horizontal or vertical surfaces within 5 feet of you. See this creature’s game statistics in the sickly trifle stat block. A trifle dissolves into nothing if it is reduced to 0 hit points, and cannot be harvested using your Stock Up feature.
Whenever you use your Campfire Cook feature, you can also create sickly trifles by converting at least 4 temporary hit points from your meal into hit points for each trifle.
The trifles last until your next long rest. You can create and control as many at once as you like, up to a maximum equal to your Wisdom modifier (a minimum of one).
When you create a trifle, you determine its color and appearance, within the bounds of its vague gelatinous form.

On each of your turns, you can take a bonus action to command the trifles to take their Slather action if you are within 60 feet of them. As part of the same bonus action, you can direct the trifles to move up to their speed. If you don’t issue any commands to them, your trifles will not move or take actions. A trifle can comfortably ride upon your person until commanded to move under its own power.

sheet.description: During a short or long rest, you can expend ingredient dice to create a pool of hit points using the same method as your Campfire Cook feature. From this pool, you create a number of sickly trifles in unoccupied spaces on horizontal or vertical surfaces within 5 feet of you.

description.p: From 10th level, creatures gain resistance to nonmagical bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage while they retain temporary hit points from your gourmet features.

description.p: At 10th level, your biology undergoes several changes as a result of your daring diet. You gain the following benefits:

ul.li: You no longer need to breathe.
You can consume food and drink by touching or holding it against your skin.
You are immune to acid damage.
You can squeeze through a space that is large enough for a creature two sizes smaller than you.

Once per short rest, you can become transparent for 1 minute. While transparent, even when in plain sight, it takes a successful DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check to spot you if you have neither moved nor attacked. A creature that tries to enter your space while unaware of you is surprised by you. You must concentrate on the transformation as if concentrating on a spell.

sheet.description: You no longer need to breathe. You can consume food and drink by touching or holding it against your skin. You are immune to acid damage. You can squeeze through a space that is large enough for a creature two sizes smaller than you. Once per short rest, you can become transparent for 1 minute. While transparent, even when in plain sight, it takes a successful DC 15 Perception check to spot you if you have neither moved nor attacked.

description.p: At 14th level, you can truthfully boast of breaking the mold with your caustic culinary inventions. As an action, you can expend an ingredient die to create a gelatinous cube. The cube swells into being around you, and you are Engulfed by the cube at the centre of its space. The cube uses its statblock from the Monster Manual, with the following changes:

ul.li: The cube has extra hit points equal to the number rolled on your expended ingredient die + your gourmet level. Any sickly trifles within 10 feet of you when the cube is created are absorbed into its mass, and their remaining hit points are also added to the cubes total hit points.
The DC of the Dexterity and Strength checks to avoid the cube’s Engulf action, or to pull a creature from the cube, now equals 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier.
While you are Engulfed by the cube, you are not restrained, and can freely enter or exit, treating the cubes space as difficult terrain.

description.p: The cube is friendly to you, and will obey your mental commands (no action required by you). In combat, the cube shares your initiative count, but it takes its turn immediately before yours.

At any time whilst the cube is within 5 feet of you, you can use an action to break the cube down into a number of sickly trifles up to your Wisdom modifier, allocating each trifle hit points as usual from the cube’s remaining hit point total.
If it is reduced to 0 hit points, or is still intact after 1 hour, the cube dissolves into a puddle of ooze. Its remains cannot be harvested using your Stock Up feature.
Once you use this feature, you must complete a short or long rest before you can use it again.

sheet.description: You can expend an ingredient die to create a gelatinous cube.

description.p: Deep in the guts of the great cities, thousands toil daily for a pittance. Unlike their wealthy employers, these hungry masses cannot rely on the luxuries of dining out, or personal cooks. Enterprising chefs, working with artificers and engineers, have risen to the occasion by automating the work of the kitchen as a means to offer a cheap, mass-produced selection of meals catering to beleaguered laborers.

For a true gourmet, however, supervising such marvels is never enough. Many choose to leave the repetitive recipes in the hands of their advanced kitchens, and strike out once more in search of new novelties to add to their menus.

A gourmet trained in the magical technologies necessary for industrial-scale catering can complement their cooking prowess with a variety of forward-thinking utensils. The most versatile - and, some might say, endearing - of these is no doubt the humble oven golem: a clay assistant fueled with a facsimile of life in aid of creating quick, quality food.
When you choose this specialty at 2nd level, you gain proficiency with potter’s tools and your choice of smith’s tools or tinkerer’s tools.

From 2nd level, you can apply a process to get more out of your ingredients at the cost of nutritional value. Over the course of 1 minute, you can convert an ingredient die into 2 dice of the size immediately below it.
For example, you can take 1d10 from your Stock to convert into 2d8s, convert 1d8 into 2d6s, and so on.
You must have room in your Stock available for the new dice to make use of this feature.

sheet.description: Over the course of 1 minute, you can convert an ingredient die into 2 dice of the size immediately below it. You must have room in your Stock available for the new dice to make use of this feature.

description.p: By 2nd level, you have built a mobile means of automating your cooking, an oven golem. It is friendly to you and your companions, and it obeys your commands. See this creature’s game statistics in the oven golem stat block. You determine the creature’s appearance and whether it has two legs or more; your choice has no effect on its game statistics.

In combat, the oven golem shares your initiative count, but it takes its turn immediately after yours. It can move and use its reaction on its own, but the only action it takes on its turn is the Dodge action, unless you take a bonus action on your turn to command it to take one of the actions in its stat block or the Dash, Disengage, Help, Hide, or Search action.

The oven golem uses ingredient dice to fuel a number of special abilities, described in its stat block below. As an action, you can store a number of ingredient dice within the golem up to 1 + your Wisdom modifier. The oven golem requires at least one ingredient die to keep its internal fires kindling: if the last ingredient die stored within it is expended, it will immediately become inert. While inert, the oven golem is incapacitated, cannot move, and fails all saving throws. It remains in this state until you use an action to restock it with at least one ingredient die.
If the mending spell is cast on it, it regains 2d6 hit points. If it reaches 0 hit points and dies, you can recover ingredient dice stored within it so long as its body remains intact.
At the end of a short rest, you can create a new oven golem if you have your potter’s tools with you. If you already have an oven golem from this feature, the first one immediately perishes.

description.p: Starting from 6th level, you may use your reaction to allow your oven golem to use your Guts feature, instead of you, if it is in a position to do so.

description.p: By 14th level, you have perfected your on-the-go methods to a degree of rigor any food regulator would be proud of. When rolling more than one of the same size of ingredient die for your Campfire Cook feature or for any of your oven golem’s actions, you may pick one of the dice rolled and count all other dice of the same size as if they had rolled the same number.

description.p: While the golem is not inert, it constantly radiates the earthy heat of the hearth. It and creatures within 15 feet of it suffer no ill effects from cold climates, as described in chapter 5 of the Dungeon Master’s Guide.

description.p: The following numbers increase by 1 when your proficiency bonus increases by 1: the golem’s skill and saving throw bonuses (above), the bonuses to hit and damage of its charred shot attack, and the number of hit points restored by its golem-fired goodies (below).

description.p: The oven golem cooks any number of stored ingredient dice of the same size to transform them into golem-fired goodies, which can be retrieved by any friendly creature within 5 feet of it as an action. A golem-fired goodie is an edible object roughly the size of a bun. It lasts for 24 hours before becoming inedible. When consumed by a creature as an action, a golem-fired goodie restores a number of hit points equal to the ingredient die used to create it + your proficiency modifier.

sheet.description: The oven golem cooks any number of stored ingredient dice of the same size to transform them into golem-fired goodies, which can be retrieved by any friendly creature within 5 feet of it as an action. When consumed by a creature as an action, a golem-fired goodie restores a number of hit points equal to the ingredient die used to create it + your proficiency modifier.

description.p: When the golem takes damage as the result of an attack, it can expend one of its stored ingredient dice to create a 20-foot radius sphere of dark smoke centered on itself. The sphere spreads around corners, and its area is heavily obscured. It lasts for 1 minute or until a wind of moderate or greater speed (at least 10 miles per hour) disperses it. If the golem would be reduced to 0 hit points by the damage it takes, it can still choose to use this reaction before falling to 0 hit points.

description.p: Many chefs, be it out of fond nostalgia, some misplaced samurai affect, or simply for good marketing, claim a signature tool of their trade. Gourmets are subject to the same habits, but for them a trusted utensil can mean much more than it would in an ordinary kitchen.

On the road, items that prove useful in varied scrapes are highly valued. Perhaps your favored utensil is also your go-to weapon when a fight breaks out - or perhaps it was a gift that reminds you of home when the lights are few and the nights are long. Consider tying your favored utensil to your gourmet’s culinary speciality, and think about what instinct drives them to reach for it first.

tr.td: A knife that doesn’t dull easily. It cuts kindling as well as it chops vegetables.
This cleaver belonged to your father, and his father before him, and his father before him...
A lucky spoon. You can always manage to find it, no matter how messy the camp.
A chopping board that has caught a bandit’s blade more than once.
The wood of this rolling pin is hard to identify, but it makes an incredibly satisfying sound.
This whisk was a parting gift from your mentor.

description.p: Locked in the mind as surely as it was once savored on the tongue, a sense memory of some emotionally charged dish is what many gourmets return to, time after time, meal after meal: the bedrock of their passion in the craft.

A sense memory might be visual, aromatic, even aural, but it almost always refers back to some pivotal moment in a gourmets life that connects their soul with food. The meal that was served at the moment of this memory may not have even been very good. What matters is a powerful sense of nostalgia, excitement, or perhaps even trauma that it carries.

tr.td: The taste of ratatouille takes you back to your farmhouse childhood and mother’s cooking.
The crackle of crusty bread brings back unwelcome reminders of invaders crunching their way across the remains of your family bakery.
The smell of roasting meat reminds you of the campfire that you and your best friend last sat around together, all those years ago.
Overpowering garlic: not to everyone’s liking. But always to his.
You had never had dessert, never had anything more than scraps, until that night at the palace.
The faintest sound of sprinkling salt conjures the particular gestures of your teacher, their finishing flourish over a deep tray ready for the oven.

description.p: A cook’s hours are long; an adventuring gourmet’s are no better, and the beds are often worse. Who can be blamed for a little indulgence at the end of the day?

If your gourmet has a penchant for sneaking secret treats, consider the severity, and the cost, of the habit. Sugar is a vice all too easily found in a kitchen, but it could be hard to come by on the open road. Is your indulgence a source of satisfaction, or shame? Perhaps your preferred relaxation food reflects poorly on your tastes among judgmental contemporaries. How your character considers their own indulgences can say a lot about them to others.
